step1.title: Download the Arduino software
step1.text: Go to http://arduino.cc/en/Main/Software and download the Arduino Software for your Windows.

step2.title: Install the Software and Connect Arduino
step2.text:
Plug in your board and wait for Windows to begin its driver installation process. 
Click on the Start Menu, and open up the Control Panel. Navigate to Device Manager, and look under Ports to find “Arduino UNO (COMxx)”.
Right click on the “Arduino UNO (COMxx)” port and choose the “Update Driver Software” option. 
Next, choose the “Browse my computer for Driver software” option.
Finally, navigate to and select the Uno’s driver file, named “ArduinoUNO.inf”, located in the “Drivers” folder of the Arduino Software download.

step3.title: Run the Arduino IDE and Start Sample Code
step3.text:
Open the Arduino Software, and make sure the board is still connected to your computer. 
Open the LED blink example sketch: File > Examples > 1.Basics > Blink. 
You’ll need to select the entry in the Tools > Board menu that corresponds to your Arduino. Select the Arduino Uno Option.
Select the serial device of the Arduino board from the Tools > Serial Port menu. On Windows, This is likely to be COM3 or higher.

step4.title: Upload Your Sample Code
step4.text:
Now, simply click the “Upload” button in the environment. Wait a few seconds – you should see the RX and TX LEDs on the Arduino flashing. If the upload is successful, the message “Done uploading.” will appear in the status bar.
A few seconds after the upload finishes, you should see the pin 13 (L) LED on the board start to blink. If it does, congratulations! You’ve got your Arduino up and running.

step5.title: Communicate Between Arduino and PC

step6.title: Upload Sample Code (Again) and Open Serial Monitor
step6.text: Click "Upload" button in the enviornment. Once the code is uploaded, click on the serial monitor in the tollbar and set the baud rate to 9600. You should be able to see the printout. EZ
